posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
You have already cross-classed Tumble, you don't need to. A Paladin / CoT / Harper Scout should fit the theme and give you a decent skillset, except UMD. Plus HS gives 2 Bonus Feats. posts.author: TyrTemplar
posts.content:
Max has some good advice for you there, Stomppa-Tomppa, which I second. The great thing--but also the trick-- about Paladins is finding the right "mix" of STR and CHA. Unless you're going all out Smite Evil, there is no need for 25+ CHA. Even then I like a STR 20 myself (on build level 40); otherwise, 22+ STR rest into CHA will net you a nice balance so as to have a decent AB/damage set-up, bring on your Paladin buffs for more as required.

Harper Scout is a good choice (has a nice skillset), but Rogue is even better, I agree. There is absolutely nothing that says a Rogue can't be LG. In fact, the opposite is true so far as Rogues as a class are not restricted to any alignment, free to train and use their skills for the cause of justice and force of good (and when combined with say a LG Paladin class, that makes them LG by defnition and thus they should!). When I think Pal/Rogue, 007 James Bond type comes immediately to mind; a secret agent in Her Majesty's Secret Service, out to save the wrold from the forces of evil, using his specialized training to scouting out the bad guys, gathering intelligence and hunting them down to stop them from destroying the world, bringing them to justice in the name of Queen and country. The Kings and Queens of past and the Church employed spies (intelligence gathering and counter-espionage), so there were Medieval O07s (Pal/Rogues) for sure! A dynamite combination--both build-wise AND RP-wise, indeed!

Smite ON! ~ Tyr

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
For more survivability:
Use items with bonus to strength and charisma.
Use items with damage reduction/resistance.
Use your spells to buff up! Don't leave home without bless, aid, bull's, cat's and GMW up. Use divine favor as often as you can.
Keep adding to strength at level up. Take the EWF, AS and EP feats in epic levels.
Get the discipline skill up to an adequate level.
Add some more to taunt if you use that skill and still have trouble hitting others.

Take at least 20 levels of paladin for full spellbook.

posts.author: TyrTemplar
posts.content:
Actually, I am going to defend the choice of Rogue here, both for RP reasons and build reasons. (Perhaps James Bond wasn't the best example, but he definitely was no doubt about it a charming Rogue ... right you are, Mick; perhaps "M" would be a much, much better example, keeping James Disciplined while ENFORCING the Code ...

Monk on a Paladin build? That is pure "CHEESE" ... it's OK, nothing wrong with it (lots of great skills, indeed), but let us call it what it is--I mean, RP? NOPE. Wearing Armor and using weapons VIOLATES 100% the Monk CODE, and lose ALL of their Monk abilities when violate their CODE. Now, I ask you: a) would a REAL monk (1 level does not for a monk make) violate the code (LG, LN or LE ONLY choice) -or- a Paladin (knight in shining armor, with the sword) make for a Paladin running around in cloth striking out with a fist (or kamas only), zero benefits with only 1 monk, or even begin to suggest a Holy Man of the Cloth (i.e. Monk) violate his own Oath when the Paladin has him/herself taken an Oath? COME ON. To avoid a Rogue due to old "impressions" of the class as being thieves, which isn't true (again, Rogues are not Limited, can be any alignment they want; as to monks, can be Lawful EVIL too you know, serving the serpent god, enslaving villages and sacrificing babies at the alter of doom). Seeing as you have already taken a few skills in traps, ROGUE works--already going the Secret Agent route, Her Majesty's Secret Service / CSIS (RCMP) / CIA. Medieval version of course, defending the people against terrorism, espionage, and bringing diabolical EVIL "master minds" to justice, in which case the only code a Pal/Rogue/CoT follows is that of the Paladin one proper.

Also, build wise: Rogue gets you a nice skills dump right away. You are playing up on a RP-server, and trust you aren't liking much all the attack of opportunities you are no doubt attacting when running around, especially when in combat. 26 Pal, 10 COT, 4 Rogue for 40 / make that: Pal 23/5 CoT/2 Rogue for lvl 30).

Yes, could put Rogue off to the end (or monk, though that doesn't in my mind work RP-wise, for reasons said, but also means a bunch of nasty AoOs, as you don't have mobility/spring attack. Tumble avoids that, which is a DEX-based non-melee skill (cross-train on a Pal/melee only as you know), and which Tumble Check to avoid AoOs is penalized when wearing heavy armor (-7 to -8 depending on the armor, with another -10 coming in if use a big board/Tower Shield). Note: when playing a pure melee be it a Paladin or what have you up, if going full-warrior of it (absent spring attack, etc.) then I cross-train as you are doing, having Cat's potions in my pack (up the Dex, in turn tumble), no need to worry about fear, etc. on a pally (unlike other melee warriors, no protect v. alignment etc. either so have need to cart clarity potions as well as Cat's, barring a Rogue or Bard in the mix, which allows for UMD--magic access, plus Tumble of course).

Now, the good Pally spell Prayer gives a nice boost (+1 all skills), such that by Lev. 40 cross-class Tumble 20 (21 points in adjusted for 8 or 9 Dex), add +1 Prayer so 21 "effective" points, netting you a final adjusted score Tumble 14 (accounting for your armor) when sleeping naked under the stars, so not attacting AoOs when walking past enemies, much less running around in combat either without anything more. Hence, by Lev. 40 all good to go, no problem at all (actually, much sooner i.e late 20s, with a little help from a dex item which should be easy to find even on a low magic setting, but the point being if x-train same as if added a single level of Monk or Rogue at the end, only difference being the "tumble class" would on a 30 lev. build +3 (AC over a build w.o a tumble class in the mix. But waiting until the end has its drawbacks: i.e., AoOs ... a bit of a pain. (Technically, could wait as playing 30 and not 40, this is an option, and a good one as Max suggests, as it does mean more AC in the end, though).

Seeing as you are adding a tumble class anyway, however, why not NOW? i.e., get that tumble. If go Rogue also means some UMD (magic access) right away, as opposed to "stocking up" and waiting for a final skills dump. This, unless your world gives out free spring attack or you can find some Boots of Tumbling (boosts tumbling) which in turn would allow you to delay that, but still nice to pick up a little magic access on a melee. A paladin doesn't need UMD, comes with the good Paladin spell book (including immunities, nice saves especially when as here combined with CoT so no concern there, with healing and other such things).

Monk--old Cleric trick, works for the tumble, but not exactly done for the RP. Rogue on the other hand, a different story: not just the tumble of course but can be anything they want, and with Paladin in particular fighting the good fight, believing in equality and freedom for all by definition, why on earth as a Paladin would you want to pre-judge an entire class, based on ... NOTHING. Rogues are NOT EVIL. But heh Monks can be (LE in fact, just as easily as LG or LN. And they do NOT wear armor or fight with weapons. Just saying...)

Just some food for thought, in defense of the Rogue class. Other skills as a Pal/COT include: Concentration (if you want to cast defensively, use with defensive casting mode), and Taunt, yes. A very nice skill for the Paladin to have, don't leave home (PvM/E) without it, I agree! In terms of Equp't, other than the Dex thing (for Tumble DC), STR and CHA, also agree. And don't pre-judge the entire Rogue class just because of a charming one by the name of James Bond, eh? THINK "M" instead--and there you go!!

Cheers

LOL!

Remind them of the Paladins of Avoreen--defense, duty, war and vigilance (god of war, and Halflings, too, but not just halflings of course, cultivating good relations--and in turn numerous followers of Human, Dwarf and Elf pantheons. This, not to mention favoured class of the Halfling? Rogue ... Dogma of Avoreen is Vigilance/keeping watch to protect against i.e. espionage and terroism, yes? CSIS, SIS (MI6), CIA, etc. Medieval times, to make the nation safer by maintaining readiness (and thus aggressive watchfulness) for incursions -- sure sounds to me like Pal/Rogue, aka "secret agent".

And yes, Rogue 3/CoT 4 works, too, but CoT 5 does give Divine Wrath--+3 AB/Damage and Saves, lasting the duration of your Cha-modifier (which Cha you're going to be enhancing any way, so why not ....). Yes, it's only once per day, but it's a nice little boost, the damage is "divine" based meaning it's not resisted. Not huge, but still nice. Uncanny prevents Dex AC (not dodge, but DEX) from being lost when flat-footed or attacked by i.e. invisible creatures (very important to a Dex-based build for obvious reasons, not so much for a Str-based plate wearer--plate allowing for a +1 AC from Dex boost). 2 rogue is good and sufficent for the skills dump, and even nets you a bit of sneak (1d6) on your sword (3 of it would make that another sneak bonus (2d6), which is cool), and the evasion brought in on Rogue (2) is nice, too. All the better for spying on and keeping watch over the bad guys, need good reflexes when a specialized secret agent, right? Either works, so up to you.

A good choice, build-wise and RP-wise, I think. Makes me sleep much better at night, on behalf of the town, knowing there are specialized agents like you out there, keeping a watchful, vigilant eye over the bad guys, maintaining a proper level of preparedness against potential incursions, war (intelligence gathering is important and an honourable calling in turn), thus ensuring the people are safe and sound. LOTS to work with there, yes? And sounds good.

Cheers

posts.author: Dante2377
posts.content:
If you're going to take fighter for weapon spec, make sure to take FTR 4 on an epic level that gives a general feat 21, 24, 27, 30), so you can take both Weapon Spec and Epic WS at the same time on that level. Also, you'll run into XP penalty taking FTR instead of CoT, so take that into consideration.

Not knowing anything about your server, I would take Toughness or Cleave over Bullheaded, given your request for better melee presence.

One area that may make a difference (but it's very AC/environment-dependent) is going with a Scimitar instead of Bastard Sword for the increased threat range for more critical hits, but that's only if you'll actually hit on the low end of that range (15-16 if no Keen available and 12-14 with Keen) to get a crit. Given that you can buff Bless, AID, and +5 from divine favor from an AB perspective, that may be a good option, especially as you have a higher STR and lots of damage buffs (holy sword, defeaning clang, GMW or +5, etc).

For PvP, your taunt will be more effective if you max it out, esp vs melee since they usually don't take concentration.

Stomppa, Good to hear.

As to FTR or COT on a Pal, both are similar (Fighter gives one extra feat and opens WS/EWS, but COT gives saves but Pal has nice saves on its own. EDIT: just to add a quick note re: gear. If in a world where say +5 items are available, remember, you get +5 perma ab boost yes (making GMW and Holy Sword redundant, save and except HS's divine damage boni vs. evil, which is still nice); however, also means that everyone/everything else gets +25perma boost to AC (i.e., dodge, armor, deflection, natural, and shield). The higher the magic, the more AC outpaces AB, meaning, you need even more natural AB (to which you'll then add solid buffs, like divine favor, aid, bless and prayer, for more). In such environs, where weaponry enhancements like GMW become redundant, HS remains useful (divine boni v evil as noted), but also made redundant if find sword with holy avenger property, so very true. In such a case, fill book with div.favor, which remains useful. Also easy to cap out your CHA (Aura/Eagle's) and STR (bull's) in such environs as well, enabling better management of not only your spell book but also equipment slots, which are not infinite. Hope this helps.

posts.author: TyrTemplar
posts.content:
Dante, in such a place, I wouldn't take spellcraft either. Gotcha.

Stomppa, what we're talking about here when it comes to ie spellcraft and saves is the fact there's a bio-cap on saves, which is set at +20. Gear applies to cap, as does CoT's sacred defense and spellcraft (spellcraft applies only to save v. spells, though, whereas sacred defense, gear, etc. applies across the board, including but not limited to just spells). Pall Cha boni doesn't count towards that cap, gaining up to +6 more assuming CHA +12 (bio stat cap). Once hit the caps, that's it. I'm not one to advocate gear-dependency but yes, if know for certain you'll get items which you'd ordinarily wear anyway that bring you to cap (without taking slots you'd otherwise want to use for something else as per Dante's e.g., and it's a good one), then no point in such environs wasting points on spellcraft when can use them (or the ability needed to get those points in order to train it) for something else, I agree.

Lots of good advice in here for you to consider, and look forward to seeing what you do!

Tyr
